speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: and how jackson public schools factors in so what we have on the ballot on tuesday august 6 is the jackson recreation millage and this has been approved since 1960 so it's one of our older millages and then it's going to be up on the ballot again this year and it's really a unique millage because it includes the city of jackson but also the entire jackson public schools district so that includes the city of jackson and then parts of our surrounding townships like blackman
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: Summit, Napoleon, and Liberty.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: So this is something that impacts the entire school district.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: So people who live in the school district will be voting on it, not just people in the city of Jackson.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: So that means that people who live in the district also get the benefit of the free and reduced recreation programs that come with the millage.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: So what this does is it offsets the cost of recreation programs.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: and it makes them affordable for youth under 18 years old and people over 50.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: So it supports our youth recreation programs and our senior programs for the entire recreation department.

text: Isn't it more than a renewal?
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: Yeah, so it's a renewal in the sense that this is voted on every 10 years, so it's not a new millage, but there is going to be a slight increase that's being asked this year.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: So in 2014, it was approved at 0.50 mils, and then this year it's going to be 0.75 mils.
speaker: SPEAKER_31

text: Today, people are paying around $50 a year for it.

text: Michigan's marijuana laws could soon be simplified.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: State Representatives Graham Filler and Jimmy Wilson Jr.
speaker: SPEAKER_20

text: have introduced bipartisan legislation that would merge Michigan's medical and recreational marijuana regulations into one set of rules.
speaker: SPEAKER_20

text: The proposal is being largely welcomed by the industry because businesses would only have to apply for one license and operate under one set of rules.
speaker: SPEAKER_20

text: Representative Filler says it's all about streamlining one of Michigan's most booming industries.
speaker: SPEAKER_20

text: I think it's an efficiency issue and I think it's removing an unnecessarily layer of regulation and
speaker: SPEAKER_18

text: Frankly, there's barely any medical left in the state of Michigan.
speaker: SPEAKER_18

text: But we still, because of the two acts, have one massive act that requires regulation, state regulation, requires individuals purchase an extra license, even for just a small amount of cannabis sold.
speaker: SPEAKER_18

text: Medical marijuana sales in Michigan have totaled just $11 million this year, less than 1% of the market.
speaker: SPEAKER_20

text: Luke Sloan for the Michigan News Network.
